titleInfo.title: Carte de Kentucke, d'après les Observations actuelles Dédiée a L'Honorable Congrès des Etats Unis de l'Amérique et à Son Excellence George Washington, Commandant en chef de les Armées (1785)

mods.abstract: John Filson's French language map of the central "bluegrass" part of Kentucky Territory published in his Histoire de Kentucke, 1785. Bounded by the Ohio, Cumberland and Green (Riviere Verte) Rivers, it shows cities and towns, Native American villages, rivers, creeks, mountains, counties, and includes commentary on certain features. Centered on the early settled area around Lexington, Harrods Town, and Boonsborough, this map names forts, salt works and springs, towns, dwellings and mills (moulins), and "cabones des sauvages," or cabins of the savages, referring to Native Americans. Early migration routes are noted, such as the roads (chemins) leading to the Cumberland settlements around Nashville and the long-established one between Virginia and Kentucky. Particular attention is given to the quality of the land as indicated by prairie or the presence of cane and the location of workable salt deposits. The mill of Col. [Daniel] Boon[e] and the fort of Col. [Isaac] Shelby, among many other named establishments, are shown.

Filson's original map (and book) was published in English the year prior to this French translation, and eventually into German. This work, like many early maps and guidebooks from the American frontier, highlighted the advantages of moving to the new territory of Kentucky, specifically the mineral resources, farmland, and modes of transportation. Filson, as a close friend of Daniel Boone, added an appendix which publicized Boone's accomplishments.
